clean_content:
Definition / general

* Common, small, benign intraoral squamoproliferation* Most common papillary lesion of oral cavity

Essential features

* Common, small (< 1.0 cm), benign intraoral squamoproliferation* Associated with HPV 6 and 11 in approximately 50% of cases* Commonly involves soft palate, tongue, lips, tonsils* Excisional biopsy curative with recurrences rare; no known association with oral or oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma* Squamous cell papilloma represents WHO 4th edition head and neck preferred nomenclature; however, in practice, squamous papilloma is commonly used

ICD coding

* ICD-10:
  + [D10.0](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D10-/D10.0) - lip+ [D10.1](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D10-/D10.1) - tongue+ [D10.2](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D10-/D10.2) - floor of mouth+ [D10.30](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D10-/D10.30) - unspecified part of mouth+ [D10.39](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D10-/D10.39) - other, specified part of mouth

Epidemiology

* Most frequently seen in third to fifth decades ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol 1980;49:419](6154913))
  + Can occur at any age* No gender predilection

Sites

* Soft palate / uvula, tongue, lips, gingiva most common intraoral sites ([Semin Diagn Pathol 2015;32:3](25749203))* Also may occur in oropharynx, larynx

Etiology

* Approximately 50% associated with HPV 6 and 11 ([Eur Arch Otorhinolaryngol 2017;274:3477](28639061))
  + Not associated with high risk HPV infection* Remaining cases may represent persistence of papillary epithelial architecture following viral clearance or may represent nonspecific epithelial alteration* No evidence of clonality

Clinical features

* Majority < 1.0 cm in size and do not show persistent growth* In setting of immunosuppression, may be larger, multifocal, less obviously papillary, more aggressive clinically ([J Oral Maxillofac Surg 2018;76:128](28727989))

Diagnosis

* Frequently suspected clinically on basis of papillary appearance* Excisional biopsy necessary for diagnosis

Prognostic factors

* Recurrence rate minimal and related to incomplete excision* Since mucosal HPV infections may persist for 1 - 2 years, patient may be at mildly elevated risk for additional squamous papillomas ([Lancet 2013;382:877](23827089))* Dypslasia infrequently encountered in squamous papillomas; generally not considered premalignant condition* No known association with oral or oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma

Case reports

* 5 year old girl with recurrent palate papilloma ([Niger J Clin Pract 2018;21:1674](30560835))* 10 year old girl with hard palate mass ([Int J Clin Pediatr Dent 2018;11:244](30131649))* 14 year old boy with hard palate mass ([Indian J Dent 2014;5:211](25565755))* 21 year old man with uvula lesion causing sore throat ([Malays Fam Physician 2019;14:74](32175046))* 43 year old man with lesion causing airway obstruction during conscious sedation ([Anesth Prog 2017;64:168](28858548))

Clinical images

Contributed by Ivan J. Stojanov, D.M.D., M.M.Sc.  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov13.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov13.jpg)

Squamous papilloma of gingiva

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov14.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov14.jpg)

Squamous papilloma of tongue

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov15.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov15.jpg)

Squamous papilloma of soft palatal mucosa

Gross description

* Papillary (cauliflower-like) and exophytic, tan-white lesion

Gross images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Hard palate tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/oralcavitysquamouspapillomapmc01.jpg)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30131649/#&gid=article-figures&pid=fig-2-uid-1)
 
[![Hard palate tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/oralcavitysquamouspapillomapmc02.jpg)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25565755/#&gid=article-figures&pid=figure-2-uid-1)

Hard palate tumor

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Papillary proliferation of stratified squamous epithelium with variable hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol 1980;49:419](6154913))
  + Hyperplasia and mitotic activity restricted to basal / parabasal layers+ Retention of cellular polarity and normal maturation in suprabasal layers* Papillary (finger-like) projections exhibit prominent fibrovascular cores
    + Hyalinization at tips of cores may be seen occasionally* Often pedunculated but may be sessile* Koilocytes rare / absent* No endophytic component* Secondarily traumatized squamous papillomas may show spongiosis, leukocyte exocytosis and absence of surface keratinization* Dysplasia in squamous papilloma characterized by cytologic abnormalities typical for epithelial dysplasia

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Ivan J. Stojanov, D.M.D., M.M.Sc.  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov01.jpg)

Pedunculated

Irritated

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov07.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov07.jpg)

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov08.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov08.jpg)

Hyalinization

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov09.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov09.jpg)

Irritated

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov10.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov10.jpg)

Mitotic activity

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov11.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov11.jpg)
 
[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov12.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavitysquamouspapillomastojanov12.jpg)

With acanthosis

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* [HPV](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainshpv.html) ISH not routinely performed for diagnosis

Sample pathology report

* Right soft palate, mucosa, excision:
  + Squamous papilloma

Differential diagnosis

* [Verruca vulgaris](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityverrucavulgaris.html):
  + Hyperkeratosis with marked hypergranulosis including large keratohyaline granules+ Axial inclination of rete ridges+ Rarely pedunculated and attached to underlying epithelium by narrow stalk+ Relatively uncommon in oral cavity* [Condyloma acuminatum](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumorwarts.html):
    + More significant epithelial hyperplasia+ Bulbous rete ridges, blunted tips of individual papillae+ Koilocytes always seen+ Relatively uncommon in oral cavity and clinical correlation beneficial* **Giant cell fibroma**:
      + Nodular proliferation of densely collagenous fibrovascular tissue+ Lage stellate and occasionally multinucleated fibroblasts present, particularly in superficial lamina propria+ Surface epithelium thinly keratinized and frequently papillary+ Rete ridges often elongated and occasionally anastamosing* [Verrucous hyperplasia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityverrucoushyperplasia.html):
        + Verrucous epithelial architecture with surface keratosis representing dysplastic phenotype+ Epithelial dysplasia may or may not be present+ Epithelium often atrophic but may be hyperplastic+ Hyperkeratosis / parakeratosis and verrucous architecture often sharply demarcated+ No true fibrovascular cores+ May or may not be seen in setting of proliferative (verrucous) leukoplakia* [Verrucous carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityverrucous.html):
          + Generally indolent histopathologic variant of squamous cell carcinoma+ Verrucous architecture with prominent hyperkeratosis / parakeratosis+ Endophytic growth pattern involving deep lamina propria or skeletal muscle in the absence of frank invasion+ Minimal to modest epithelial atypia / dysplasia* [Focal epithelial hyperplasia (Heck disease)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitymultifocalepithelialhyperplasia.html):
            + Often multifocal+ Epithelial hyperplasia with subtle to absent papillary features+ Mitosoid bodies characteristic: karyorrhectic cells with fragmented chromatin* [Inflammatory papillary hyperplasia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitypapillaryhyperplasia.html):
              + Reactive condition exclusively seen in denture wearers or mouth breathers+ Generally presents as diffuse involvement of hard palatal mucosa+ Nodular / papillary proliferation of fibrovascular tissue+ Variable lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate+ Epithelium exhibits leukocyte exocytosis and spongiosis+ Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia may be present
